items.title: Trump signs executive order to transfer TikTok to US owners
items.standfirst: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. items.title: Murdoch’s TikTok? Trump offers allies another lever of media control
items.standfirst: Under the known terms of the deal with China, TikTok would get a new board, including Murdochs and EllisonsDonald Trump revealed last week the US and China are close to inking a deal to let TikTok continue operating in the US. Details are not final, but should the agreement go through as has been reported, the owners of the US’s most powerful cable TV channels may soon also steer the nation’s most influential social network. The arrangement would gift Trump’s billionaire allies a degree of control over US media that would be vast and unprecedented.Here’s what we know. Under the known terms of the deal, which Trump declared has the tentative buy-in of Chinese president Xi Jinping, TikTok in the US would get a new group of US investors, led by the US software giant Oracle, which would license TikTok’s vaunted recommendation algorithm and take over its security. Continue reading...
items.content: Under the known terms of the deal with China, TikTok would get a new board, including Murdochs and EllisonsDonald Trump revealed last week the US and China are close to inking a deal to let TikTok continue operating in the US. Details are not final, but should the agreement go through as has been reported, the owners of the US’s most powerful cable TV channels may soon also steer the nation’s most influential social network. The arrangement would gift Trump’s billionaire allies a degree of control over US media that would be vast and unprecedented.Here’s what we know. Under the known terms of the deal, which Trump declared has the tentative buy-in of Chinese president Xi Jinping, TikTok in the US would get a new group of US investors, led by the US software giant Oracle, which would license TikTok’s vaunted recommendation algorithm and take over its security. Continue reading...

Some of Trump's allies are poised to take control of TikTok's algorithm.
Trump vowed to block Israeli annexation of West Bank ahead of Netanyahu visit.

items.title: Why Amazon actually got off easy despite ‘historic’ $2.5 billion Prime deceptive practices settlement
items.standfirst: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday announced a $2.5 billion settlement with Amazon just days into a trial over the tech giant’s alleged use of deceptive practices that the commission said for years tricked millions of consumers into signing up for a Prime membership without their knowledge,…
items.content: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday announced a $2.5 billion settlement with Amazon just days into a trial over the tech giant’s alleged use of deceptive practices that the commission said for years tricked millions of consumers into signing up for a Prime membership without their knowledge,…

items.title: Amazon to pay $2.5bn for allegedly duping millions to sign up for Prime
items.standfirst: While a win for consumers and the FTC, the settlement is relatively painless for Amazon which makes $2.5bn in 33 hours.
items.content: While a win for consumers and the FTC, the settlement is relatively painless for Amazon which makes $2.5bn in 33 hours.

items.title: Amazon Will Pay $2.5 Billion to Settle FTC Suit That Alleged ‘Dark Patterns’ in Prime Sign-Ups
items.standfirst: Amazon will pay both the Federal Trade Commission and consumers directly to settle a lawsuit alleging that it used manipulative and deceptive tactics to encourage sign-ups for Prime.
items.content: Amazon will pay both the Federal Trade Commission and consumers directly to settle a lawsuit alleging that it used manipulative and deceptive tactics to encourage sign-ups for Prime.

items.title: Amazon agrees $2.5bn settlement for allegedly duping customers into Prime membership
items.standfirst: Amazon has reached a historic $2.5bn (£1.9bn) settlement with a US business watchdog over allegations it tricked customers into signing up for Prime membership.
items.content: Amazon has reached a historic $2.5bn (£1.9bn) settlement with a US business watchdog over allegations it tricked customers into signing up for Prime membership.

items.title: Amazon to pay $2.5bn to settle FTC lawsuit over Prime ‘subscription traps’
items.standfirst: US regulator said company enrolled millions of customers into service without consent and made it difficult to cancelAmazon has agreed to pay $2.5bn in fines and redress to Prime subscribers to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), which accused the retail giant of signing users up for the service without their consent and making it difficult to cancel.In a statement, the FTC said $1.5bn of the total will go into a fund to repay eligible subscribers, on top of a $1bn civil penalty. Continue reading...
items.content: US regulator said company enrolled millions of customers into service without consent and made it difficult to cancelAmazon has agreed to pay $2.5bn in fines and redress to Prime subscribers to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), which accused the retail giant of signing users up for the service without their consent and making it difficult to cancel.In a statement, the FTC said $1.5bn of the total will go into a fund to repay eligible subscribers, on top of a $1bn civil penalty. Continue reading...

items.title: Amazon to Pay $2.5 Billion Over Prime Subscriptions
items.standfirst: Amazon.com Inc. agreed to pay $2.5 billion in penalties and refunds and change its process for how to cancel its Prime subscription to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission.
items.content: Amazon.com Inc. agreed to pay $2.5 billion in penalties and refunds and change its process for how to cancel its Prime subscription to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission.

ai_summary: Amazon will pay $2.5 billion to settle a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit.
The FTC alleged Amazon used deceptive tactics to sign up Prime members.
The settlement includes $1.5 billion for eligible subscribers' refunds.
Amazon will also pay a $1 billion civil penalty as part of the settlement.
The settlement addresses how Amazon handles Prime subscription cancellations.

clusters.title: Jail time for Sarkozy: Why the unprecedented sentence over Libya financing?
clusters.neutral_headline: Former French President Sarkozy Sentenced to Five Years in Prison

items.title: Jail time for Sarkozy: Why the unprecedented sentence over Libya financing?
items.standfirst: France's former leader Nicolas Sarkozy sentenced to five years for his part in the illegal financing of his 2007 campaign by Muammar Ghaddafi's Libya. He'll do time... even during his appeal. That's on top of his electronic bracelet he wore in a seperate case of eavesdropping on magistrates. "I'm innocent," insists the conservative leader...
items.content: France's former leader Nicolas Sarkozy sentenced to five years for his part in the illegal financing of his 2007 campaign by Muammar Ghaddafi's Libya. He'll do time... even during his appeal. That's on top of his electronic bracelet he wore in a seperate case of eavesdropping on magistrates. "I'm innocent," insists the conservative leader...

items.title: Sarkozy’s spectacular downfall marks turning point in France’s struggle against graft
items.standfirst: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday – for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi – it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday – for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi – it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in jail but with head held high’ after conviction
items.standfirst: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in prison, but with head held high’ following guilty verdict in Libya trial – as it happened
items.standfirst: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France’s interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.… Continue reading...
items.content: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France’s interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.… Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy sentenced to 5 years in prison in Libya corruption trial
items.standfirst: Former French president found guilty of conspiring to receive campaign contributions from Muammer Gaddafi
items.content: Former French president found guilty of conspiring to receive campaign contributions from Muammer Gaddafi

items.title: From power to prison: The stunning downfall of France's former president Nicolas Sarkozy
items.standfirst: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.
items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy says he is innocent in Libya trial, will appeal conviction
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.

items.title: Former French president Sarkozy given five-year sentence after Libya case

items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy, president from 2007-12, was found guilty of criminal conspiracy but cleared of other charges.

items.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison
items.standfirst: For the first time in French history, a former president has been sentenced to prison. Nicolas Sarkozy was handed a five-year sentence by a Paris court for criminal association tied to alleged Libyan financing of his 2007 campaign. Though acquitted of the most explosive corruption charges, the ruling marks a seismic shift in France's political and judicial landscape. Joining us for in-depth analysis, Delano D'Souza welcomes Philippe Moreau Chevrolet, Professor of Political Communications and Public Affairs at Sciences Po and President of MCBG Conseil.
items.content: For the first time in French history, a former president has been sentenced to prison. Nicolas Sarkozy was handed a five-year sentence by a Paris court for criminal association tied to alleged Libyan financing of his 2007 campaign. Though acquitted of the most explosive corruption charges, the ruling marks a seismic shift in France's political and judicial landscape. Joining us for in-depth analysis, Delano D'Souza welcomes Philippe Moreau Chevrolet, Professor of Political Communications and Public Affairs at Sciences Po and President of MCBG Conseil.

items.content: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison.

items.title: Former FBI director James Comey indicted for making false statement to Congress and obstruction of justice
items.standfirst: Indictment comes after Trump instructed US attorney general to prosecute Comey and others he considers political foesUS politics – latest updatesJames Comey, the former FBI director and one of Donald Trump’s most frequent targets, was indicted on Thursday on one count of making a false statement to Congress and one count of obstruction of justice, according to a person familiar with the matter, in the latest move in the president’s expansive retribution campaign against his political adversaries.“No one is above the law. Today’s indictment reflects this Department of Justice’s commitment to holding those who abuse positions of power accountable for misleading the American people. We will follow the facts in this case,” Pam Bondi, the US attorney general, tweeted on Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: Ancient skull from China redraws human family tree, researchers say

items.standfirst: Starbucks' overhaul will cost $1 billion as it shutters locations and cuts 900 nonretail employees.
items.content: Starbucks' overhaul will cost $1 billion as it shutters locations and cuts 900 nonretail employees.

items.title: Starbucks to close underperforming stores in restructuring efforts
items.standfirst: The cuts are expected to lead to hundreds of layoffs.
items.content: The cuts are expected to lead to hundreds of layoffs.

ai_summary: Starbucks CEO announced plans to close underperforming stores.
The restructuring will cost the company one billion dollars.
The company will shutter locations as part of the overhaul.
Starbucks will cut 900 nonretail employee positions.
Hundreds of layoffs are expected due to the closures.

clusters.title: Trump urges Turkey to stop buying Russian oil as Erdogan chases deal on F-35s
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Urges Turkey to Stop Buying Russian Oil

items.title: Trump urges Turkey to stop buying Russian oil as Erdogan chases deal on F-35s
items.standfirst: The US president suggests the US could lift sanctions on Turkey and allow it to buy F-35 jets.
items.content: The US president suggests the US could lift sanctions on Turkey and allow it to buy F-35 jets.

items.title: Trump urges Turkey's Erdogan to stop buying Russian oil in White House meeting
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Thursday urged his Turkish counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdogan to stop buying Russian oil over the war in Ukraine as the two leaders met at the White House. Trump signalled willingness to revive Turkey’s suspended F-35 deal and lift sanctions linked to Ankara’s purchase of Russian missile systems.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday urged his Turkish counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdogan to stop buying Russian oil over the war in Ukraine as the two leaders met at the White House. Trump signalled willingness to revive Turkey’s suspended F-35 deal and lift sanctions linked to Ankara’s purchase of Russian missile systems.

ai_summary: Trump urged Turkey's Erdogan to stop buying Russian oil.
The meeting occurred at the White House.
Trump signaled willingness to revive the F-35 deal.
He also indicated lifting sanctions on Turkey.
The sanctions are linked to Turkey's Russian missile purchase.

clusters.title: Denmark says 'professional actor' behind drone incursions over its airports
clusters.neutral_headline: Denmark Says 'Professional Actor' Behind Drone Incursions

items.title: Denmark says 'professional actor' behind drone incursions over its airports
items.standfirst: But the defence minister says there is no evidence of Russian involvement after the latest incident.
items.content: But the defence minister says there is no evidence of Russian involvement after the latest incident.

items.title: Denmark says 'professional actor' using airport drones 'to spread fear'
items.standfirst: Another Danish airport has been forced to close due to drone sightings - with a minister calling it a "professional" operation designed to cause fear.
items.content: Another Danish airport has been forced to close due to drone sightings - with a minister calling it a "professional" operation designed to cause fear.

ai_summary: Denmark says a "professional actor" is behind drone incursions.
The incursions occurred over Danish airports.
The defense minister stated no evidence of Russian involvement.
Another airport was forced to close due to drone sightings.
The minister called it a "professional" operation to cause fear.

clusters.title: Trump claims escalator 'triple sabotage,' demands probe despite U.N. explanation
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Demands Probe of UN "Triple Sabotage

items.title: Trump claims escalator 'triple sabotage,' demands probe despite U.N. explanation
items.standfirst: Trump demanded an investigation into what he called a “triple sabotage” at the United Nations General Assembly, including the now infamous halted escalator.
items.content: Trump demanded an investigation into what he called a “triple sabotage” at the United Nations General Assembly, including the now infamous halted escalator.

items.title: Trump demands inquiry over UN 'triple sabotage' after escalator and teleprompter mishaps
items.standfirst: The US president called the incidents that included an escalator and teleprompter mishap "a real disgrace".
items.content: The US president called the incidents that included an escalator and teleprompter mishap "a real disgrace".

ai_summary: Trump demanded an investigation into "triple sabotage" at UN.
The incidents included an escalator malfunction.
A teleprompter mishap also occurred.
Trump called the incidents a "real disgrace".
The UN provided an explanation for the incidents.
